Dead Gods

The Dead Gods were the God creators of Marlien, so called by the Charon because they seem to have at one time entered into their Creation, but then destroyed themselves. The Dead Gods are God or Gods which created Marlien. The name first came from the mouths of the Charon, given both to the true creator or creators which afterward entered into Marlien, and the second, who were created by the fission of the true.

True

The creator or creators named the True Gods of Marlien entered into it at the dawn of time, and were responsible for the creation of the first progenitor race, which they interacted with somewhat before the fission.

Other Names

  • First
  • Creators
  • Makers

Second

The Second resulted from the fission of the True Because the second form of the dead gods dwelt in Marlien for a time, and held dominion over mortals, they came to be given ancient names, which became their true names. Each embodied one motivation of the True, and was almost single-minded in its pursuit - especially regarding the creation of the second progenitor race.

  • T'hechtonon, Second of Knowledge
  • Hlidera, Second of Beauty
  • Ubrikant, Second of Dynamism
  • Betrodum, Second of Predestination
  • Gelfexinerey, Second of Magiks
  • Sathlid, Second of Luck

Other Names

  • Dissonance

History

The True entered into Marlien at the dawn of time, deeming their view from the Great Beyond too imprecise and warped by the manipulation by lesser atam of its internal_mechanisms. They intended to reform it drastically from within, where they could more clearly witness the results of their changes, and act as a guiding hand for all time. They were greeted at their arrival by the first progenitor race, whom they had prepared ahead to aid them in sculpting the early world.

Upon entry into their Creation and first perception of temporal existence, however, the First realised almost immediately that their own perfectionist nature and competing goals would lead to naught but a cycle of destruction and redesign which would last until the end of time; this was the primary cause of the lack of clarity they had perceived from the Great Beyond - far more disruptive than the actions of lesser atman. With a few words to the first progenitor race they then engineered, much to the dismay of the Charon, their own fission, dividing their desires into the Second, that they may come to some imperfect solution to their disparate desires through conflict and natural selection, rather than endless deliberation. In this fission the True created one entity above all others - a lesser form of their whole, to observe the actions of the Second and see that all was not turned to ruin, and it was called the Arbiter.

The Second did a great many things across the world, and resolved for the most part all disputes through compromise, but their focus met eventually on the creation of a second race, for they grew tired of the short-lived, heavy-handed, dim-witted first progenitor race. In creation of the second progenitor race they found themselves not in conflict with eachother, however, but with their own wilful, precocious, magically gifted, long lived, and intelligent creation, which seemed to both twist and exceed their design at every opportunity. Furthermore, they desired the removal of the first progenitor race now that the world was mostly formed, but the giant sculptors filled the second progenitor race with wonder, and so not all were complicit in the Seconds' effort to destroy them. While there was some conflict, the vast majority of the second progenitor race were quickly turned to the defence of their predecessors, which would have been hopeless were it not for the secret support of the Arbiter.

Unions between the first progenitor race and the second progenitor race produced the human progenitor race, a race sharing in the strengths of both their progenitors: wise, tough, hard workers, and incredibly inventive. human progenitor races bred far more quickly than the short-lived first progenitor race or the immortal second progenitor race, and soon were the most numerous of the three peoples. What is more, they were more fickle than the second progenitor race: they lived longer lives than the first progenitor race, and long enough to become discontent that they could not enjoy the immortality of the second progenitor race. They were easily swayed by the machinations of the Second, and moved to the betrayal of, and war against their parent races.

There was great conflict in the unified cities of the three races, and eventually the majority of the human progenitor race were outcast. With the hardiness of the first progenitor race and the intellect and cunning of the second progenitor race these human progenitor race began to reshape the world outside to their liking, building their own cities with ease, along with temples from which to worship the Second.

At this point, the most-part of the Second were pleased with the human progenitor race, who fulfilled all their original desires accordingly, not exceeding or twisting their design, and being well obedient. The Arbiter too was pleased, and being the most powerful remnant of the True, seeing that the Second had fulfilled their purpose, moved to bring about their end. The means by which this was done is unknown, but it resulted in a massive release of mana, and left almost no trace of the True, the Second, or the Arbiter.

In this event the Marlien Girdle was infused with such a quantity of mana that the resident soul stewards together do not wield enough mana to tear it down should they decide that the Creation is too hazardous for resident atman. As a result, they have settled in for the long-haul, carving out their own plane, The Halls of the Charon, and creating a legion of charon mortals to help guard the other trapped atman.

Remnants

The entity Tingma is a remnant of the removal of these Gods, perhaps a fraction resulting from further fission and fusion of the Second.

The Second T'hechtonon sought some method of avoiding this final removal from the world, possibly by encasing itself in a physical body of mana-infused anicca, the corpse of which still floats through the Astral plane, concealing a vast reservoir of mana.
